This section presents our system model and communication model for the proposed vehicular FL platform.
Moreover, for convenience, we summarize the main notations in Table I.

For our learning model, we use 111 gated recurrent unit (GRU) layer with 161616 hidden layers, SGD (momentum=0.95) optimizer with learning rate 0.0010.0010.001, Î¼=0.1ğœ‡0.1\mu=0.1, l=15ğ‘™15l=15, and hâˆˆ{1,â€¦,12}â„1â€¦12h\in\{1,\dots,12\}.
We select 101010 agents with ÏvâˆˆUâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹fâ€‹oâ€‹râ€‹mâ€‹(0.2,0.8)subscriptğœŒğ‘£ğ‘ˆğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘“ğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘š0.20.8\rho_{v}\in Uniform(0.2,0.8) GHz and Î·vâˆˆUâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹fâ€‹oâ€‹râ€‹mâ€‹(104,404)subscriptğœ‚ğ‘£ğ‘ˆğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘“ğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘šsuperscript104superscript404\eta_{v}\in Uniform(10^{4},40^{4}) cycles/sample.
Furthermore, the agents use 11:00âˆ’16:30:110016:3011:00-16:30 trajectory data samples as their training dataset. We devise the global round update time in such a way that at the beginning, there are enough data samples to train the model, and the training data samples ğ’Ÿkvsuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘£\mathcal{D}_{k}^{v} only use data samples from 11:00:00:1100:0011:00:00 to the global round update time in a causal manner.
This means that the proposed FL solution is implemented in an online fashion, in which the vehicles gather data as they travel along their trajectory.
Other key V2X simulation parameters are listed in Table II.
We first show delays between two global communication rounds using the simulation parameters in Table II.

We next show average training loss for
all forecast window sizes using our proposed vehicular FL solutions amalgamating with FedProx and FedAvg. Table III shows that the prediction accuracy degrades as the forecast window size hâ„h increases.
Therefore, one should carefully choose the forecast window size based on the required accuracy by the applications such as velocity and VSP prediction.
Furthermore, FedProx works better than FedAvg. Accordingly, FedProx based FL solution is more suitable for IoV networks.
